[![Coverage Status](https://coveralls.io/builds/11112913/badge)](https://coveralls.io/builds/11112913)

Coverage decreased (-8.2%) to 61.628% when pulling **e863ca776b61ef46cb3b938478f79757751f5916 on jkff:needs-runner** into **810db7f990a9e39179f3613347ab5cde7e7c650c on apache:master**.

Would it be preferable instead to augment the join library to handle more than two PCollections. I'm wary of a huge number of features being added to CoGroupByKey (especially as it it set to become the grouping primitive in lieu of "ordinary" GroupByKey). 

An alternative would be to expose this FilterFn that a user could apply immediately following a CoGBK. (One could also imagine options that require at most (or even exactly) one element per iterable, and unwrap them.)

Good point @robertwb 

Agree to separate the filter options from core code of `CoGroupByKey`, let me move it to a separate class like `CoGbkResultFilterFn`, can add outer_join later.

The ideal way is to update `join-library`. It's more complex as `join-library` uses KV in the implementation which is fixed with two sources, would see how to handle it in another task.
I'm very much not a fan of the no-else-return changes (it obfuscates the code when the else block is an alternative, not a continuation). Thoughts on disabling this warning instead?

Coverage decreased (-0.1%) to 70.53% when pulling **f603d606b9ea1c1231c57b39d2b805b582b274df on pabloem:remove-agg-java** into **8302783c3239ddcf8b5259b4aff8ee33673d02cd on apache:master**.

hrm. No, the rest of the code does not handle a CannotProvideCoderException.

I had thought based on my notes/discussion at the time when I created the JIRA issue that this was basically a documentation issue and that from a logical perspective it'd be okay to let coder inference happen later, but adding "throws CannotProviderCoderException" to source's getDefaultOutputCoder shows a couple holes. I'm guessing this is one of those changes where the changes will ripple out a bit (eg https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/sdks/java/core/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/Read.java#L108 and https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/runners/core-construction-java/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/runners/core/construction/UnboundedReadFromBoundedSource.java#L179 - that second one makes it seem like we're just moving the "I need a coder registry" problem to a different location.)

I can definitely do the investigation/wiring/testing work if people think this is useful, relevant now and there aren't any known traps out there for me to find. It seems like for adapter sources like the HIFIO, being able to say that you don't know the coder beforehand and instead rely on coder inference would be very handy. The work to make https://github.com/apache/beam/blob/master/sdks/java/io/hadoop/input-format/src/main/java/org/apache/beam/sdk/io/hadoop/inputformat/HadoopInputFormatIO.java#L350 work  involved passing in a coder registry to the source from the outer transform, which felt dirty. It'd be nice to just check to see if there is a known coder, and throw CannotProvideCoderException if that's not the case. 

If we don't want to do this work, it may be nice to instead do the work to provide the coder registry to sources in a straightforward way.

cc @kennknowles since I know he cares about this.

R: @dhalperi so it gets picked up in the dashboard.

I'm a little confused by this PR. For functional / integration tests, it seems important to test that reading works without the write transform, and that writing works without the read transform.

Why doesn't this lose coverage?

[In another discussion I recall discussing we didn't need to do this for performance tests, specifically because we would already have test coverage of correctness in the "standard" IOITs]

Is this needed on its own? E.g., is the gRPC code that talks to Pub/Sub broken at HEAD?

Otherwise, prefer to only make upgrades for a reason (like, part of Spanner support).
R: @dhalperi
